column2: The contribution of the sectors covered by the EU ETS with respect to the EU Climate ambition should be of -62% compared to 2005
column5: The implementation of TA6.7 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.23, as reducing greenhouse gas emissions in the EU ETS sector will contribute to achieving the overall goal of reducing net greenhouse gas emissions by at least 55% by 2030.

column2: The contribution of the sectors covered by the EU ETS with respect to the EU Climate ambition should be of -62% compared to 2005
column5: The implementation of TA6.7 will also have a positive impact on TA2.24, as the reduction in greenhouse gas emissions will help achieve the target of reducing energy consumption by at least 11.7% in 2030.

column2: The contribution of the sectors covered by the EU ETS with respect to the EU Climate ambition should be of -62% compared to 2005
column5: Furthermore, TA6.7's implementation will positively affect TA2.25, as reducing energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions will lead to a decrease in buildings' final energy consumption.

column2: The decline of pollinators is reversed
column5: The reversal of pollinator decline, as stated in TA6.8, is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.37, which aims to increase the share of renewable energy in the electricity mix, as pollinators play a crucial role in maintaining ecosystem health and biodiversity.

column2: The risk and use of chemical pesticides is reduced by 50%, and the use of more hazardous pesticides is reduced by 50%
column5: However, the reduction in chemical pesticide use, as outlined in TA6.9, may have a negative impact on TA2.37, as some renewable energy sources, such as bioenergy, may rely on pesticides for crop management.

column2: The obligation to set up urban wastewater collecting systems is extended to all agglomerations with a p.e. of 1.000 or more and all source of urban wastewater should be connected to them
column5: The implementation of TA7.1 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.38, which aims to increase offshore wind capacity, as reducing wastewater pollution will help maintain marine ecosystem health and support the development of offshore wind farms.

column2: Improve soil quality by reducing nutrient losses and chemical pesticides’ use by 50% (target partially in common with the Farm to Fork strategy and Biodiversity strategy) - focus on soil quality and pesticides
column5: The improvement in soil quality, as stated in TA7.10, will positively affect TA2.40, which aims to decarbonize primary steel production, as reducing nutrient losses and chemical pesticide use will lead to more sustainable agricultural practices and potentially increase the availability of biomass for steel production.

column2: Improve soil quality by reducing nutrient losses and chemical pesticides’ use by 50% (target partially in common with the Farm to Fork strategy and Biodiversity strategy) - focus on water quality and chemical pesticides
column5: However, the focus on reducing chemical pesticide use in TA7.11 may have a negative impact on TA2.40, as some steel production processes may rely on pesticides for material protection.

column2: Develop measures to significantly increase efforts to identify, investigate, assess and remediate contaminated sites, so that soil pollution will no longer pose a health or environmental risk
column5: The development of measures to remediate contaminated sites, as outlined in TA7.12, is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.41, which aims to reduce waste generation, as cleaning up contaminated sites will reduce the amount of hazardous waste and promote more sustainable land use practices.

column2: Improve air quality to reduce the number of premature deaths caused by air pollution by 55%
column5: The improvement in air quality, as stated in TA7.13, will positively affect TA2.42, which aims to increase the share of renewable energy in the electricity mix, as reducing air pollution will lead to a decrease in the negative impacts of fossil fuel-based energy production.

column2: Improve water quality by reducing waste, plastic litter at sea (by 50%) and microplastics released into the environment (by 30%)
column5: The improvement in water quality, as outlined in TA7.14, is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.43, which aims to increase the share of renewable energy in the electricity mix, as reducing water pollution will help maintain marine ecosystem health and support the development of offshore renewable energy sources.

column2: Improve water quality by reducing waste, plastic litter at sea (by 50%) and microplastics released into the environment (by 30%)
column5: The implementation of TA7.15 will also have a positive impact on TA2.44, which aims to increase the share of renewable energy in the heating and cooling sector, as improving water quality will lead to a decrease in the negative impacts of fossil fuel-based heating and cooling systems.

column2: Reduce by 25% the EU ecosystems where air pollution threatens biodiversity
column5: The reduction in air pollution, as stated in TA7.16, is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.45, which aims to increase the share of renewable energy in the transport sector, as reducing air pollution will lead to a decrease in the negative impacts of fossil fuel-based transportation.

column2: Reduce the share of people chronically disturbed by transport noise by 30%
column5: The reduction in transport noise, as outlined in TA7.17, will positively affect TA2.46, which aims to increase the share of renewable energy in the transport sector, as reducing noise pollution will lead to a decrease in the negative impacts of fossil fuel-based transportation.

column2: Reduce significantly total waste generation and by 50% residual municipal waste
column5: The reduction in waste generation, as stated in TA7.18, is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.47, which aims to increase the share of renewable energy in the industry sector, as reducing waste will lead to a decrease in the negative impacts of fossil fuel-based industrial processes.

column2: Improve soil quality by reducing nutrient losses and chemical pesticides’ use by 50% (target partially in common with the Farm to Fork strategy and Biodiversity strategy) - focus on water quality and nutrient loss
column5: The improvement in soil quality, as outlined in TA7.19, will positively affect TA2.48, which aims to increase the share of renewable energy in the agriculture sector, as reducing nutrient losses and chemical pesticide use will lead to more sustainable agricultural practices and potentially increase the availability of biomass for energy production.

column2: Having all soils in healthy condition by 2050
column5: The goal of having all soils in healthy condition, as stated in TA7.20, is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.49, which aims to increase the share of renewable energy in the agriculture sector, as healthy soils will lead to more sustainable agricultural practices and potentially increase the availability of biomass for energy production.

column2: Minimise or eliminate the use of pesticides in sensitive areas such as urban green areas
column5: However, the minimization or elimination of pesticide use in sensitive areas, as outlined in TA7.21, may have a negative impact on TA2.50, which aims to increase the share of renewable energy in the industry sector, as some industrial processes may rely on pesticides for material protection.

column2: The revision of the Ambient Air Quality Directives would merge the Directives into one, and seek to: align EU air quality standards more closely with WHO recommendations further improve the legislative framework
column5: The revision of the Ambient Air Quality Directives, as outlined in TA7.22, is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.51, which aims to increase the share of renewable energy in the electricity mix, as improving air quality will lead to a decrease in the negative impacts of fossil fuel-based energy production.

column2: Remove micropollutants from wastewater
column5: The removal of micropollutants from wastewater, as stated in TA7.23, will positively affect TA2.52, which aims to increase the share of renewable energy in the heating and cooling sector, as reducing micropollutants will lead to a decrease in the negative impacts of fossil fuel-based heating and cooling systems.

column2: Improve nutrient removal from wastewater
column5: The improvement in nutrient removal from wastewater, as outlined in TA7.24, is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.53, which aims to increase the share of renewable energy in the transport sector, as reducing nutrient pollution will lead to a decrease in the negative impacts of fossil fuel-based transportation.

column2: Member States shall ensure that the total final energy consumption of all public bodies combined is reduced by at least 1.9% each year, when compared to 2021
column5: The reduction in energy consumption, as stated in TA2.21, is likely to have a positive impact on TA6.7, which aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions in the EU ETS sector, as reducing energy consumption will lead to a decrease in greenhouse gas emissions.

column2: Member States shall collectively ensure a reduction of energy consumption of at least 11.7% in 2030 compared to the projections of the 2020 EU Reference Scenario
column5: The reduction in energy consumption, as outlined in TA2.22, will positively affect TA6.8, which aims to reverse the decline of pollinators, as reducing energy consumption will lead to a decrease in the negative impacts of fossil fuel-based energy production on ecosystems.

column2: Member States shall make efforts to collectively contribute to the indicative Union primary energy consumption target amounting to no more than 992.5 Mtoe in 2030
column5: However, the reduction in primary energy consumption, as stated in TA2.23, may have a negative impact on TA6.9, which aims to reduce the risk and use of chemical pesticides, as some energy production processes may rely on pesticides for crop management.

column2: Each Member State shall ensure that at least 3% of the total floor area of heated and/or cooled buildings that are owned by public bodies is renovated each year to be transformed into at least nearly zero-energy buildings or zero-emission buildings
column5: The renovation of buildings, as outlined in TA2.24, is likely to have a positive impact on TA6.10, which aims to improve soil quality, as reducing energy consumption in buildings will lead to a decrease in the negative impacts of fossil fuel-based energy production on ecosystems.

column2: Reduce buildings' final energy consumption by 14%
column5: The reduction in buildings' final energy consumption, as stated in TA2.25, will positively affect TA6.11, which aims to reduce nutrient losses and chemical pesticides' use, as reducing energy consumption will lead to a decrease in the negative impacts of fossil fuel-based energy production on ecosystems.

column2: At least double the annual energy renovation rate of residential and non-residential buildings by 2030 and to foster deep energy renovations
column5: The increase in energy renovation rate, as outlined in TA2.26, is likely to have a positive impact on TA6.12, which aims to develop measures to significantly increase efforts to identify, investigate, assess and remediate contaminated sites, as reducing energy consumption will lead to a decrease in the negative impacts of fossil fuel-based energy production on ecosystems.

column2: Indicative national targets aiming to achieve the deep renovation of at least 35 million building units by 2030 to support reaching an annual energy renovation rate of 3% or more for the period till 2050
column5: The deep renovation of buildings, as stated in TA2.27, will positively affect TA6.13, which aims to improve air quality, as reducing energy consumption will lead to a decrease in the negative impacts of fossil fuel-based energy production on air quality.

column2: Reduce buildings' energy consumption for heating and cooling by 18% compared to 2015 levels by 2030
column5: The reduction in buildings' energy consumption, as outlined in TA2.28, is likely to have a positive impact on TA6.14, which aims to reduce the share of people chronically disturbed by transport noise, as reducing energy consumption will lead to a decrease in the negative impacts of fossil fuel-based transportation on air quality.

column2: For the non-residential building stock, the revised rules require to gradually improve it via minimum energy performance standards
column5: The improvement in energy performance standards, as stated in TA2.29, will positively affect TA6.15, which aims to reduce significantly total waste generation and by 50% residual municipal waste, as reducing energy consumption will lead to a decrease in the negative impacts of fossil fuel-based energy production on waste generation.

column2: The revised directive will make zero-emission buildings the new standard for new buildings
column5: The implementation of zero-emission buildings, as outlined in TA2.30, is likely to have a positive impact on TA6.16, which aims to improve soil quality by reducing nutrient losses and chemical pesticides' use, as reducing energy consumption will lead to a decrease in the negative impacts of fossil fuel-based energy production on ecosystems.

column2: All existing buildings should be transformed into zero-emission buildings
column5: The transformation of existing buildings, as stated in TA2.31, will positively affect TA6.17, which aims to remove micropollutants from wastewater, as reducing energy consumption will lead to a decrease in the negative impacts of fossil fuel-based energy production on water quality.

column2: 100% of on-site energy consumption to be covered by renewable energy
column5: The use of renewable energy, as outlined in TA2.32, is likely to have a positive impact on TA6.18, which aims to improve nutrient removal from wastewater, as reducing energy consumption will lead to a decrease in the negative impacts of fossil fuel-based energy production on water quality.

column2: The national measures will have to ensure that at least 55% of the decrease of the average primary energy use is achieved through the renovation of the worst-performing buildings
column5: The renovation of worst-performing buildings, as stated in TA2.33, will positively affect TA6.19, which aims to reduce the share of people chronically disturbed by transport noise, as reducing energy consumption will lead to a decrease in the negative impacts of fossil fuel-based transportation on air quality.

column2: Each Member State will adopt its own national trajectory to reduce the average primary energy use of residential buildings by 16% by 2030 and 20-22% by 2035
column5: The reduction in primary energy use, as outlined in TA2.34, is likely to have a positive impact on TA6.20, which aims to improve soil quality by reducing nutrient losses and chemical pesticides' use, as reducing energy consumption will lead to a decrease in the negative impacts of fossil fuel-based energy production on ecosystems.

column2: Member States will also have to set out specific measures on the phase-out of fossil fuels in heating and cooling with a view to a complete phase-out of boilers powered by fossil fuels by 2040
column5: The phase-out of fossil fuels, as stated in TA2.35, will positively affect TA6.21, which aims to reduce significantly total waste generation and by 50% residual municipal waste, as reducing fossil fuel use will lead to a decrease in the negative impacts of fossil fuel-based energy production on waste generation.

column2: See ‘Commission welcomes political agreement on new rules to boost energy performance of buildings across the EU’
column5: The improvement in energy performance, as outlined in TA2.36, is likely to have a positive impact on TA6.22, which aims to improve air quality, as reducing energy consumption will lead to a decrease in the negative impacts of fossil fuel-based energy production on air quality.

column2: By 2030, the share of renewable energy in the electricity mix should double to 55-60%, and projections show a share of around 84% by 2050
column5: The increase in renewable energy share, as stated in TA2.37, will positively affect TA6.23, which aims to reduce the share of people chronically disturbed by transport noise, as increasing renewable energy will lead to a decrease in the negative impacts of fossil fuel-based transportation on air quality.

column2: The strategy sets targets for an installed capacity of at least 60 GW of offshore wind by 2030 and at least 300 GW by 2050
column5: The increase in offshore wind capacity, as outlined in TA2.38, is likely to have a positive impact on TA6.24, which aims to improve soil quality by reducing nutrient losses and chemical pesticides' use, as increasing renewable energy will lead to a decrease in the negative impacts of fossil fuel-based energy production on ecosystems.

column2: The strategy sets targets for an installed capacity of at least 1 GW of ocean energy by 2030 and at least 40 GW by 2050
column5: The increase in ocean energy capacity, as stated in TA2.39, will positively affect TA6.25, which aims to remove micropollutants from wastewater, as increasing renewable energy will lead to a decrease in the negative impacts of fossil fuel-based energy production on water quality.

column2: Around 30% of EU primary steel production is expected to be decarbonised on the basis of renewable hydrogen
column5: The decarbonization of steel production, as outlined in TA2.40, is likely to have a positive impact on TA6.26, which aims to improve nutrient removal from wastewater, as reducing greenhouse gas emissions will lead to a decrease in the negative impacts of fossil fuel-based energy production on water quality.

column2: The use of renewable hydrogen in Europe was negligible up to 2023
column5: The increase in renewable hydrogen use, as stated in TA2.41, will positively affect TA6.27, which aims to reduce the share of people chronically disturbed by transport noise, as increasing renewable energy will lead to a decrease in the negative impacts of fossil fuel-based transportation on air quality.
